citation.article-title: Iamia majanohamensis gen. nov., sp. nov., an actinobacterium isolated from sea cucumber Holothuria edulis, and proposal of Iamiaceae fam. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Iamia (I.a′mi.a. N.L. fem. n. Iamia arbitrary name formed from the acronym of the Institute of Applied Microbiology at the University of Tokyo, which has made significant contributions to microbiology).
Cells are Gram-positive, non-endospore-forming rods that are non-motile.
Colonies grow aerobically, but not anaerobically.
In media devoid of sodium chloride, growth is observed.
Cell wall contains glutamic acid, alanine and meso-DAP.
The peptidoglycan type is presumed to be A1γ.
The peptidoglycan is of the glycolyl type.
The major cellular fatty acids are 17 : 0, 17 : 1ω8c, 15 : 0 and 16 : 0.
The type species is Iamia majanohamensis.
